questions.text: Which among the following is pressure epiphysis
questions.solution:
Pressure epiphysis takes part in joint formation and transmits weight. The head of the humerus is a pressure epiphysis as it forms the shoulder joint and bears load during movements.

Types of Epiphysis:

  1. Pressure Epiphysis – Participates in joint formation and weight transmission (e.g., head of humerus, lower end of radius).
  2. Traction Epiphysis – Non-articular, does not transmit weight (e.g., greater/lesser trochanter of femur, greater/lesser tubercle of humerus, mastoid process).
  3. Atavistic Epiphysis – Once independent but fused for nutrition (e.g., coracoid process of scapula, os trigonum).
  4. Aberrant Epiphysis – Not always present (e.g., head of the first metacarpal, base of other metacarpals).

The other options (elbow joint, wrist joint, and sternum) are not classified as pressure epiphyses.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common site of an osteoporotic fracture?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A – Vertebrae:

  • Osteoporotic or pathologic fractures commonly occur in the vertebrae, known as wedge compression fractures, typically resulting from a flexion force. These fractures usually maintain stability as the posterior elements remain intact.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C & D:

  • Fractures in osteoporosis typically result from low-trauma incidents, such as falls from standing height or less. However, fractures in locations like the subtrochanteric region, glenoid, and midshaft of the humerus often require higher forces. The initial fracture in osteoporosis often involves the distal radius (Colles’ fracture), followed by vertebral and hip fractures if not treated promptly.

questions.text: A 23 year old male reports severe pain, swelling, and an inability to extend his knee after a fall. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Patellar fracture:

  • The X-ray is an anteroposterior view of the knee showing a fracture of the patella.
  • Radiographs revealed a comminuted patellar fracture. There is moderate knee joint effusion.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Rheumatoid arthritis: The given X-ray does not exhibit symmetrical joint space narrowing, a classical radiological feature of rheumatoid arthritis.

Option C - Hemarthrosis: The X-ray does not display widening of the intercondylar notch, a radiological feature commonly associated with hemarthrosis.

Option D - Tibial condylar fracture: The provided X-ray does not reveal any fracture of the tibial condyle.

questions.text: Identify the zone of calcification in the image given below.
questions.solution:
Correct Option A -A:

 

The provided image illustrates the zones of the physis, with zone A representing the zone of calcification, also referred to as the zone of provisional ossification.

Incorrect Options:

Options B - B: Zone B in the diagram indicates the zone of hypertrophy.

Option C - C: Zone C in the illustration represents the zone of proliferation.

Option D - D Zone D in the diagram corresponds to the reserve zone.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presents with thigh pain. A CT scan was done as given below. Identify the condition.?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Chronic Osteomyelitis:

  • The CT scan provided reveals chronic osteomyelitis, with its primary role being the detection of sequestrum, a characteristic feature best visualized using this imaging technique.
  • CT and MRI scans collectively demonstrate the extent of bone destruction, reactive edema, concealed abscesses, and sequestra within the affected area.

Incorrect Options:

Option A :Osteomalacia: Looser's zones or milkman fracture or pseudofracture is seen on the radiograph.

Option B:Osteosarcoma: Sunburst or sunray pattern of periosteal reaction is seen on x-ray.

Option C: Ewings sarcoma: Shows Bone outgrowth continuous with the cortex/ Mushroom appearance

questions.text: Identify the structure marked in the given image.
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Posterior rib:

  • The given X-ray is an anteroposterior view of the chest.
  • The structure marked is posterior ribs which can be identified as transverse white lines.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C & D are incorrect

questions.text: A patient presents with low back pain. Bone scan reveals the characteristic "Honda H" sign. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Bilateral sacral insufficiency fracture

Explanation:

  • The “Honda H” sign on a Bone scan refers to a specific pattern of fracture lines seen in the sacrum, which is suggestive of Bilateral sacral insufficiency fractures.
  • Bilateral sacral insufficiency fractures typically occur in elderly patients or those with osteoporosis, chronic steroid use, or other metabolic bone diseases. It can also happen in patients with Rheumatoid arthritis.
  • These fractures are caused by normal or physiological stress on weakened bone.

Acute osteomyelitis (Option A) would typically show localized bone marrow edema with possible abscess formation but does not produce the “Honda H” sign.

Marrow edema (Option B) is a non-specific finding that can result from trauma, infection, or inflammation but lacks the specific fracture pattern of the “Honda H” sign.

Metastatic sacral lesion (Option D) usually appears as destructive or infiltrative lesions on MRI, not the bilateral linear fracture pattern of the “Honda H” sign.

questions.text: At what age in women DEXA scan is done routinely?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - At 65 years:

  • Routine DEXA scan, which is used to measure bone mineral density, is typically recommended for women at the age of 65 years. This age is chosen because it is considered the threshold age for increased risk of osteoporosis and fractures in women.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B,C - routine DEXA scan is not typically recommended at this age unless there are specific risk factors present.

questions.text: Following a fall in the bathroom, an elderly lady is diagnosed with fractured neck of the femur. Which of the following coexisting conditions most likely predisposed to this?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Osteoporosis:

  • Osteoporosis is a condition characterized by decreased bone density and increased bone fragility, making individuals more susceptible to fractures, especially in the hip, spine, and wrist. In the case of an elderly lady who experienced a fall and was diagnosed with a fractured neck of the femur (hip fracture), osteoporosis is a likely contributing factor.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Osteopetrosis:Osteopetrosis is a rare genetic disorder characterized by increased bone density and abnormal bone growth. While it can lead to brittle bones and increased risk of fractures, it is a rare condition and not commonly the underlying cause of fractures in elderly individuals following falls.

Option C - Osteoarthritis: Osteoarthritis is a degenerative joint disease characterized by the breakdown of cartilage in the joints, it does not directly affect bone density or increase the risk of fractures.

Option D - Osteomalacia: Osteomalacia is a condition characterized by softening of the bones due to vitamin D deficiency or problems with vitamin D metabolism. Osteomalacia is more commonly associated with generalized bone pain, muscle weakness, and fractures in weight-bearing bones.
